qas.question: In what year did the state of New York pass a law to free the slaves?
What borough was home to a notable population of free African-Americans?
Along with John Jay, who founded the New York Manumission Society?
In what year did the state of New York eliminate slavery?
In 1840, about how many African-Americans lived in New York City?
The gradual abolition act in New York was formed in what year?
When was slavery completely outlawed in the state of New York?

context: Under New York State's gradual abolition act of <a0_0><a5_0>1799<a5_0/><a0_0/>, children of slave mothers were born to be eventually liberated but were held in indentured servitude until their mid-to-late twenties. Together with slaves freed by their masters after the Revolutionary War and escaped slaves, a significant free-black population gradually developed in <a1_0>Manhattan<a1_0/>. Under such influential United States founders as <a2_0>Alexander Hamilton<a2_0/> and John Jay, the New York Manumission Society worked for abolition and established the African Free School to educate black children. It was not until <a3_0><a6_0>1827<a6_0/><a3_0/> that slavery was completely abolished in the state, and free blacks struggled afterward with discrimination. New York interracial abolitionist activism continued; among its leaders were graduates of the African Free School. The city's black population reached more than <a4_0>16,000<a4_0/> in 1840.
